places.title: Lake Tahoe
places.description: Resting on the California-Nevada border, Lake Tahoe has long been a favorite vacation spot, welcoming about 15 million visitors each year. Travelers are drawn here by the steep granite cliff sides and towering mountaintops, as well as the crystal-clear waters that have earned Lake Tahoe the reputation of being one of the most beautiful bodies of water in the United States. While the stunning blue lake alone is worth a trip, the surrounding area, also known as Lake Tahoe, boasts miles of hiking trails, dozens of picture-perfect vistas and some of the best skiing in North America.

places.title: Catalina Island
places.description: Sitting about 22 miles off the coast of Los Angeles, this island paradise isn't hard to reach – the Catalina Express will get you here in an hour from Long Beach – but it will be hard to leave. Boasting everything from wild bison (which roam the interior of the island) to upscale boutiques and restaurants in Avalon, Catalina Island constantly wows travelers with its diverse offerings and unparalleled natural beauty. Whether you're planning a daytrip or a relaxing weekend getaway, there are countless ways to spend your time here, from zip lining and snorkeling to sipping cocktails on the beach.

places.title: Yosemite National Park
places.description: One of California's most formidable natural landscapes, Yosemite National Park features nearly 1,200 square miles of sheer awe: towering waterfalls, millennia-old sequoia trees, striking, daunting cliff faces and some of the most unique rock formations in the United States. But despite its enormous size, most of the tourist activity takes place within the 8-square-mile area of Yosemite Valley. Here you'll find the park's most famous landmarks – Half Dome and El Capitan – as well as excellent hiking trails through the natural monuments.

places.title: Mammoth Lakes
places.description: If you've never thought of the Golden State as a ski destination, Mammoth Lakes might change your mind. Nestled in the Eastern Sierra region, Mammoth Lakes is home to the Mammoth Mountain Ski Area, the highest ski resort in the state. In winter, the region's 150-plus trails welcome skiers, ice skaters and snowboarders in droves. When the temperatures rise and the snow melts, vacationers can try other outdoor activities, such as hiking, rock climbing, paddleboarding and taking a dip in the area's hot springs.

places.title: Sequoia National Park
places.description: If you want an eyeful of the state's iconic, towering sequoias during your California vacation, there's no better place to visit than Sequoia National Park. These magnificent trees are native to the western slope of the Sierra Nevada mountain range in central California. The Giant Forest, the park's main attraction, features 8,000-plus sequoias, which stand as tall as the average height of a 26-story building. You'll also stumble upon the General Sherman Tree, the largest tree in the world by volume.

places.title: Big Bear Lake
places.description: No matter what time of year you decide to visit this rugged alpine town, located about 80 miles northwest of Palm Springs, you'll be treated to scenic mountain vistas and plenty of outdoor adventures. Nestled in the San Bernardino National Forest, Big Bear Lake (one of the top lakes in California) is popular for its excellent fishing and boating opportunities. In summer, enjoy adventurous pursuits like hiking, mountain biking and kayaking, and in winter, go skiing and snowboarding at Big Bear Mountain Resort. When you need a break from all the action, check out the shops and restaurants at The Village at Big Bear Lake.

places.title: Half Moon Bay
places.description: For a quiet reprieve from city life, check out the quaint coastal community of Half Moon Bay, which lies approximately 30 miles south of San Francisco. When you're not lounging at the town's namesake beach, which boasts 4 miles of sandy shoreline, stroll along the scenic Coastside Trail for terrific views of the Pacific Ocean and the surrounding hills. When hunger starts to set in, head downtown for a bite to eat at one of Half Moon Bay's local restaurants before indulging in a glass of wine at one of the destination's wineries.

places.title: Kings Canyon National Park
places.description: Head to Kings Canyon National Park if you want to see more of California's famous sequoias after visiting Yosemite and Sequoia national parks. The park's most famous tree is the General Grant Tree, the second-largest tree in the world by volume. Named after former President Ulysses S. Grant in 1867, the tree has been lovingly designated "the Nation's Christmas Tree" since 1926. Aside from admiring Kings Canyon's sequoias, outdoor enthusiasts can enjoy hiking, horseback riding and rock climbing, among other activities.

places.title: Joshua Tree National Park
places.description: Sitting approximately 130 miles east of Los Angeles, Joshua Tree National Park’s roughly 800,000 acres are excellent for enjoying outdoor activities. Visitors can tackle some of the park's thousands of rock climbing routes or explore dozens of hiking trails, though they should be mindful of the weather- many of the paths should not be attempted on especially hot days. Other must-do activities include biking, horseback riding and stargazing; this International Dark Sky Park offers little light pollution, making it a superb place to admire the Milky Way

places.title: Death Valley National Park
places.description: Bearing the exclusive title of the lowest, hottest and driest place in the United States, Death Valley National Park deserves a spot on every traveler's bucket list. This one-of-a-kind destination straddling the California-Nevada border can be experienced on a self-guided auto tour of Badwater Road or Artists Drive, or by hiking the popular Dante's View trail. Other must-do activities in Death Valley include viewing exhibits at the Furnace Creek Visitor Center, watching the sunrise at Zabriskie Point and stargazing from the Mesquite Flat Sand Dunes. For the best weather, arrive between November and March (in summer, the park's average daytime temperature can often surpass 120 degrees).
